column9:
941430: Load the relevant packages, the Election Campaign 2022 dataset and the Election Campaign codebook.
In this quiz we will explore how a usual suspect sociodemographic variable, age, is related to political attitudes.
As our dependent variable / response variable, the quiz will use four different survey questions capturing political attitudes.
The names of the four response variables are:

Extra_FaithInPublicHospitalSystem
Extra_CompensateInflation
Extra_ImmigrationIsAThreat
Extra_UnemployedDontDoEnough

The labels are somewhat indicative of what the response variables capture. But it is always a good idea to use the codebook to understand the survey questions and scaling properly! I have been to one too many presentations, where the "direction" of the regression coefficient was misunderstood since the scaling of the regressor or response variable was misinterpreted.
Use the codebook to answer: What does a value of "4" mean on the Extra_CompensateInflation variable?
column11: 941431: When can you join datasets together for analysis in R?
column13: 941432: Why is Z-standardization useful in data analysis?
column15: 941433: What is the primary goal of OLS regression?
column17: 941458: On a scale from 0 (the worst possible quiz for this course) to 10 (the best possible quiz for this course), how would you rate the quiz, that you have just completed?

column23:
941438: Before running a regression analysis it is always important to get a sense of the data we are analysing.
For example, by running a histogram on the age variable we see two respondents are much older than 100 years. This is highly unlikely, so we will filter out these respondents.
Use the same code to inspect the variable Extra_UnemployedDontDoEnough in a histogram with a binwidth of 1.
Which of the two statements describes the distribution better?

What is the correlation coefficient? (write your answer with three digits)

column29:
941451: No matter which attitude variable you investigated before, the coefficient would be significant. Does this mean we are ready to publish our first paper?
Not exactly. A good rule of thumb is that if you cannot visualize a result, it is not substantially important, even though it might be statistically significant. This is because with a large enough N, and enough statistical power, even the smallest statistical relationships can be statistically significant.
Therefore you should now visualize the relationship between age and the idea that immigration is a threat in a jittered scatter plot.
Do you think the relationship between the two variables is substantially important? Describe the relationship between the two variables and give your verdict!

column29: Despite of the relatively low R2 value at 0.017, there's seemingly a substantially important relationship between the two variables. column57: The relationship between age and the idea that the unemployed don't do enough is slightly negative. This indicates that older people might think that unemployed don't do enough a little bit more. But it is still important to note that the slope is almost flat and there is a big spread among the data points. This shows us that the idea that unemployed don't do enough is more randomly distributed between different age groups. The relationship is therefore not substantially important.

column47:
The jittered scatter plot shows most respondents have responded 4 or 5 meaning there is an overall high level of faith in the public hospital system. 

The relationship between age and faith in the Public Hospital System does not look to be substantially important. The scatterplot shows more the distribution of answers where it is clear that most respondents have answered 4 on a scale of 1-5 ranging their faith in the public hopsital system. There is no big difference or trend when looking at different ages and comparing their responses using the scatterplot. It looks as though for each age group there is the similar trend that fewest people have respondend 1, second fewest responded 2, third fewest responded 3, second most responded 5 and the most respondents in each age group responded 4.
